awd_titl_txt: CAS: Can the Ionic Character of 1st Row and the Covalency of 2nd and 3rd Row Transition Metals Converge?
awd_abstract_narration:
General Public Abstract:
The Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division of the National Science Foundation supports the research of Professor Peter T. Wolczanski of Cornell University. The project seeks to train candidates in the fields of metal-centered chemistry. Most commodity (bulk) and fine (pharmacological) chemicals are synthesized utilizing catalysts. These catalysts are typically transition metal compounds that accelerate the rates of reaction. Many of these catalysts use metals that are in low abundance, toxic, and expensive. This program is studying the synthesis of cheaper catalysts, but they must be modified by organic materials -- termed ligands -- in order to provide the chemical reactivity necessary to replace the current generation of catalysts used in industry. One general solution being explored is the investigation of ligands that promise to render the cheaper metals more versatile or adaptable. Another general approach is to synthesize metal systems that will underpin truly transformative processes:  the preparation of compounds that are capable of multistep chemical reactions. A specific application targets the synthesis of complexes using propellar-shaped molecules that rupture to give what are called alkylidene ligands.  Synthesis of alkylidene-metal compounds would have broad implications for the advanced manufacturing within the U.S. chemical industry. The Cornell group is also supports STEM education of 5th grade and high school students.  The STEM efforts include lecture materials and hands-on training modules.  These activities are helping to strengthen the workforce available to support the US chemical industry.

Technical Abstract:
The Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division of the National Science Foundation supports the research program of Professor Peter T. Wolczanski of Cornell University. The project seeks to train PhD candidates in the fields of inorganic and organometallic chemistry. The research identifies several reactions that are potentially transformative in regards to commodity (bulk) and fine (pharmacological) chemicals production. Typical transition metals used in catalysis are in low abundance and costly, and the work proposes to supplant these species with inexpensive 1st and 2nd row species. Various ligand platforms that display redox non-innocence, including a reversible C-C bond formation, are employed to expand the redox capacity of several first-row metals. Other 3- coordinate chelates are also involved in H-transfer chemistry to further expand the scope of reactivity.  Exploration of ionic vs. covalent bonding is fundamental to the work. Transfer HX and H2 additions, akin to transfer hydrogenations, and processes like hydroformylation, are targeted with early metal systems. Specific systems show potential for tandem CH activation in conjunction with olefin metathesis, leading to a net exchange of H2 for CH2, and one tridentate ligand has the potential for an alternate polymerization mechanism to Ziegler-Natta. Unique strained reagents are employed as alkylidene generators for numerous transition metals, as replacing expensive Ru-based olefin metathesis catalysts is an important target. The production of independent, versatile PhDs capable of adapting to a challenging and fluctuating academic or industrial market is a major objective, and the further development of Charge Distribution Via Reporters (CDVR) as a pedagogical alternative to formal oxidation states will continue to be tested. The Cornell group is also preparing a general 5th grade outreach program for publication based on experience, and is developing a related outreach program for high school students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Broader Impacts. The project "Can the Ionic Character of 1st Row and the Covalency of 2nd and 3rd Row Transition Metals Converge?" describes investigations on inexpensive and relatively non-toxic transition metals that have the potential of displacing current metals involved in crucial catalytic (a catalyst facilitates a specific chemical reaction) and materials applications. New ligands -- principally organic materials that surround and bind to the transition metal -- have been exploited and shown to expand the reactivity of 1st row transition metals, which often do not have the capacity to undergo the desired reactivity. In the course of study, a process generating olefin-metathesis catalysts in situ was developed, and a provisional patent was filed, but austerity during the pandemic prevented Cornell University from filing the final patent, and the process was published and is available to all.

            Crucial "product(s)" of this grant are the students trained for chemical industry and academia. The grant supported or partially supported four graduate students and five undergraduates during its 48 mos. of duration. Three PhD students graduated, and two are currently employed in industry (DuPont) and a naval research lab, while the third is a postdoctoral fellow seeking an academic position. Ten substantial publications have resulted from the research in addition to the three theses, and 2-3 additional papers are anticipated, despite interference from aspects due to the pandemic. There have been twelve presentations (10 poster and 2 lectures) presented at local (3) and national (9) meetings to disseminate this information. In lieu of public outreach, and due to pandemic constraints, a tutorial detailing elemental properties is one of the publications.

            Intellectual Merit. Many of the transition elements that would be desirable to conduct crucial catalytic processes do not have the intrinsic character necessary. Modification of these elements, typically in the first row, such as chromium, iron, etc. can be implemented via the use of ligands. A type of chelate  -- binds at more than one site --  ligand that can modify the electronic nature of the complex (complex = metal/ligand) in addition to binding is termed redox non-innocent (RNI). Essentially, these ligands buffer the system by giving or accepting electron density such that the metal retains a relatively constant charge. In this way, the metal can accommodate both substrate and reagent as the ligand modulates the charge by distributing electron density in the system. A spate of chelates that modify the metal by accepting electrons through multiple bonding were discovered, and are flexible enough to be employed by every 1st row transition metal. In addition, two new types of RNI were identified. Metric analyses of one system showed that variation in sigma-bonding -- direct M-L interactions -- proved crucial to attenuating the metal. A second type of RNI was identified as a reversible C-C bond that can hold and release two electrons.

            Fundamental information was also discovered in the course of investigating RNI. Nitrosyl (NO) complexes, crucial intermediate species in environmental nitrification cycles, are often thought of as positively charged entities when bound, but a statistical analysis based on infrared spectroscopy, and scrutiny of some new nitrosyl chemistry showed that NO is never bound as a positive entity. This realization effects how many aspects of industrial and environmental chemistry should be construed. Nitroxyl ligands were also employed as redox non-innocent ligands and many new species were synthesized that reveal diverse bonding and reactivity.

            An unusual "propellane" reagent that generates metal-carbon double bonds without any byproducts was used to generate ruthenium olefin metathesis catalysts in situ. An exhaustive application to all first-row transition metal elements failed to elicit any operational catalysts, despite some literature reports that indicate plausibility. The results debunk the possibility of iron olefin metathesis catalysts, and proffer an explanation why the likelihood of their existence is extremely doubtful. The search for catalysts containing metals cheaper than Ru led to "collateral success", as new chemistry was found, including rare silicide complexes. Two additional titanium systems show potential for ring-opening metathesis polymerization (ROMP), a type of olefin-metathesis that is more easily discovered, and research in these directions is continuing.

Broader Impacts. The project "Can the Ionic Character of 1st Row and the Covalency of 2nd and 3rd Row Transition Metals Converge?" describes investigations on inexpensive and relatively non-toxic transition metals that have the potential of displacing current metals involved in crucial catalytic (a catalyst facilitates a specific chemical reaction) and materials applications. New ligands -- principally organic materials that surround and bind to the transition metal -- have been exploited and shown to expand the reactivity of 1st row transition metals, which often do not have the capacity to undergo the desired reactivity. In the course of study, a process generating olefin-metathesis catalysts in situ was developed, and a provisional patent was filed, but austerity during the pandemic prevented Cornell University from filing the final patent, and the process was published and is available to all.

The grant supported or partially supported four graduate students and five undergraduates during its 48 mos. of duration. Three PhD students graduated, and two are currently employed in industry (DuPont) and a naval research lab, while the third is a postdoctoral fellow seeking an academic position.  Fundamental information was also discovered in the course of investigating RNI.
